terrain.surface: Gravel roads through European Alps. Multi-stage format with significant elevation and Alpine scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Commercial multi-stage event. Alpine terrain with professional organization but very high costs keep it in Tier 3.

biased_opinion.summary: Haute Route Gravel is a commercial multi-stage event across European Alps‚ÄîAlpine terrain with significant elevation. The professional organization and Alpine scenery are impressive, but the very high costs (‚Ç¨1500-2500+ plus travel) keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A professionally organized Alpine multi-stage gravel event. Worth it for wealthy cyclists seeking a supported Alpine experience. Not practical for most riders due to very high costs.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you have a large budget and want a supported Alpine multi-stage experience‚Äîmaybe. For most riders‚Äîthere are better value options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: Ardenne Gravel Stages, Trans-Sylvania Epic. For similar Alpine terrain: local Alpine races.

logistics.airport: Varies by year (typically Geneva, Zurich, or regional)
logistics.lodging_strategy: Included in package or arranged by organizers.

non_negotiables.why: European Alpine multi-stage requires sustained effort over multiple days.

logistics.explanation: Multi-day Alpine stage racing requires complex coordination, but actual rider experiences show gaps. Maxime Cauchois needed to pre-order nutrition from Gelvio before the event, suggesting limited on-site support. Mark Gilmour noted strict daily time cuts that create DNF pressure, while riders report that official accommodation packages deliver 'acceptable, but barely' hotels with 'sub-par' food according to multiple participants.

length.explanation: 350 miles across multiple Alpine stages delivers serious accumulated fatigue. Maxime Cauchois described the toll: 'After 4h already' of riding before tackling the hardest climbs, while juanandresso reported complete leg exhaustion despite 4.3 w/kg FTP: 'By the second or third day of the event, my legs were completely cooked. The delayed onset muscle soreness was intense and felt way beyond what I'd normally experience.' Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands. As Rupert Guinness puts it: "Haute Route Alps was also a ride 'back in time.' The mountains ridden are steeped in cycling history... The passes we tackled read like a brutal week at the Tour de France: Col de la Lombarde (20."

technicality.explanation: Alpine terrain emphasizes sustained climbing over technical handling skills. Maxime Cauchois described Col d'Agnel as 'a tale of two climbs: the first one, that averages about 5% over about 11km, is manageable... [then] 9km at 10% average, with ramps up to 14%.' The challenge lies in gradient and altitude rather than technical descents, though Rupert Guinness noted the Col de la Lombarde descent 'requires constant attention.' Less technical than The Mid South. As Rupert Guinness puts it: "As each climb passed under our wheels, the process of breaking the stage down mountain-by-mountain helped to ease any anxiety..."

elevation.explanation: 30,000 feet over 350 miles means serious vertical density through Alpine passes. Stage One climbs 'up ski runs and under ski lifts up to the Col de la Croix-de-Coeur overlooking all of Verbier' while Stage Two tackles 'the famous Col du Grand St. Bernard.' The sustained elevation gain through high Alpine terrain delivers mountain suffering. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score. As Rupert Guinness puts it: "Haute Route Alps was also a ride 'back in time.' The mountains ridden are steeped in cycling history... The passes we tackled read like a brutal week at the Tour de France: Col de la Lombarde (20."

climate.explanation: High Alpine conditions create physiological demands beyond weather. Mark Gilmour had to adjust his refueling strategy after cramping: 'I wasn't replenishing the salts I was losing through sweating and the effort' and added more salt to prevent further issues. The multi-day exposure at altitude requires constant attention to hydration and electrolyte management across varying mountain weather conditions. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Climbs reach significant elevation through Swiss Alpine passes like Col du Grand St. Bernard, with routes offering 'incredible views over the Bernese alps, the Rhone river valley, and all the way to Mont Blanc.' The altitude provides noticeable effects for sea-level riders without requiring extreme acclimatization. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

adventure.explanation: Routes traverse historic Alpine passes steeped in cycling and cultural history. Rupert Guinness described it as 'a ride back in time' through 'mountains steeped in cycling history' where 'passes we tackled read like a brutal week at the Tour de France.' The adventure extends beyond cycling to experiencing the same legendary climbs used in professional racing, following ancient trade routes through iconic European mountain terrain.

prestige.explanation: The Haute Route brand built reputation on road events, expanding into gravel through the acquired Gravel Epic series. Created in 2019 and backed by IRONMAN Group since 2021, it positions itself as 'unprecedented in the cycling and gravel events industry' but lacks the established gravel racing credibility of purpose-built events. As Official description puts it: "Since its beginning in 2011, the single event has expanded to a series of races across the world designed to give riders a challenging, immersive, and premium experience through the world's most iconi..."

race_quality.explanation: Events feature 'Full Mechanical Assistance, Full Medical Assistance, Feed Stations with local products' plus 'photographer, videographers, and drone pilots to capture the Epic-ness.' The unique format times only climbs for competition while allowing social riding between segments, though overall execution depends on translating road event expertise to gravel logistics.

experience.explanation: Multi-day format through 'fields and meadows' past 'blackened barns and chalets darkened in alpine sun over centuries' following 'ancient bisses, the ingenious Swiss irrigation systems.' The philosophy promises riders can 'ride like a pro with premium level services' across bucket-list Alpine terrain with professional support infrastructure.

community.explanation: The road Haute Route attracts riders seeking that 'pro-cyclist lifestyle taste' - serious amateurs with deep pockets and deeper delusions about their abilities. Without confirmed gravel events, there's no actual community yet, just spillover from the road scene. You'll get the same type A personalities, just arguing about tire pressure instead of aero wheels.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, the gravel racing scene splits into 'adventure gravel for bikepacking' versus 'race gravel for those chasing speed and performance' with equipment ranging from 'ultralight climbing machines to aero-optimised speed demons.' E-gravel bikes are permitted, suggesting a broad participant base rather than deep competitive field depth. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Frank Persyn puts it: "At least 2 gels per hour during every ride, feeding myself within 20 mins after the finish followed by a proper massage."

value.explanation: Premium European multi-day events with 'half board Official Race Accommodation packages' and full support services mean significant costs. The IRONMAN Group backing and positioning as 'unprecedented in the cycling and gravel events industry' suggests luxury pricing that prioritizes premium experience over value proposition.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs ‚Ç¨1500-2500. Multi-day European stage racing with accommodation packages, international travel requirements, and premium support services create substantial costs. Team entry options and e-gravel bike inclusion suggest accessibility attempts, but the fundamental expense structure of supported Alpine stage racing remains prohibitive for most riders. More expensive than Atlas Mountain Race.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Where on earth are we? Haute Route Mexico
videos.description:
It wouldn't be me if something ridiculous didn't happen...
With custom bike brand Wyndymilla, I flew into Mexico City to ride the first ever Haute Route Mexico in Valle de Bravo but..... we got really lost on the way to the start. Haute Route are some of the best multi-day road cycling climbing events in the world so I was gutted when I thought I'd missed it.

https://www.wyndymilla.com

Instagram: http://instagram.com/julietelliott
Bikes n' Stuff: http://www.bikes-n-stuff.com
My store: https://www.amazon.co.uk/shop/julietelliott
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/juliet.elliott
Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/_julietelliott
Strava: https://www.strava.com/athletes/julietelliottuk

I have the following sponsors and my videos contain products given to me by them. 
https://www.assosofswitzerland.com
https://www.sram.com
https://www.zipp.com
https://www.smithoptics.com
https://uk.foxracing.com

videos.title: GCN VS Jenson Button - Riding The Haute Route Oman
videos.description:
Haute Route Oman invited us out to take part in their inaugural event, and Ollie leapt at the chance to compete at road cycling's premier amateur event, and that was before he found out that he'd be racing Jenson Button. 

In association with Haute Route Oman.

GCN Sale still on: https://gcn.eu/1id
Subscribe to GCN: http://gcn.eu/SubscribeToGCN
Register your interest in the GCN Club: https://gcn.eu/1ic

Check out Ollies full route here: https://gcn.eu/komoothr

Submit your content with our new uploader: http://gcn.eu/upload
Join our Facebook community: http://gcn.eu/FBCommunity 

If you enjoyed this video, make sure to give it a thumbs up and share it with your friends. üëç

The Global Cycling Network puts you in the centre of the action: from the iconic climbs of Alpe D‚ÄôHuez and Mont Ventoux to the cobbles of Flanders, everywhere there is road or pav√©, world-class racing and pro riders, we will be there bringing you action, analysis and unparalleled access every week, every month, and every year. videos.title: The BATTLE FOR the G.C. IS ON!! üî• Stage 4 Haute Route Pyrenees
videos.description:
After my successful attack on Col du Tourmalet in stage 3, I was eager to gain more time the riders in front of me in the GC! On stage 4 of Haute Route Pyrenees we had 2 big climbs of which the last one was really tough: 20km of climbing on Cap de Long! In the first 3 stages I got to know the other riders and it was time to make some friends and choose my battles! My best bet: attack in the descent! 

This is my experience of the Haute Route Pyrenees 2022. Haute Route is the hardest and most complete multi day event you can ride as an amateur cyclist. The stages are very similar to the Grand Tours of World tour Professianal cycists. In this event we raced 5 stages in 5 days, 627km and 15.700m of elevation, starting in Biarritz and ending in Saint Lary. 

Watch the 5-episode Documentary this week: 
üçøSTAGE 1 https://youtu.be/aHxmp5z3Aek
üçøSTAGE 2 https://youtu.be/TomR1ScSl7Y
üçøSTAGE 3 https://youtu.be/VQgAapzY81A
Friday Dec 9th: STAGE 4
Sunday Dec 11th: STAGE 5 (final episode)

videos.curation_reason: Recent first-person race experience with detailed course specifics and competitive strategy from Haute Route Pyrenees.

videos.title: GCN Rides The Haute Route Alps
videos.description:
Thanks to the Haute Route for inviting us to ride this year's Haute Route Alps. All opinions are the presenter's own.

Subscribe to GCN: http://gcn.eu/SubscribeToGCN
Register your interest in the GCN Club: http://gcn.eu/pb
Get exclusive GCN gear in the GCN shop! http://gcn.eu/pc

Join John ‚ÄúChocolate Voice‚Äù Beavan as he tackles arguably the toughest amateur cycling event in the world, the Haute Route Alps. Over 7 days, and more than 22,200m of elevation on some of the most iconic climbs in cycling, John battled his way from Nice to Geneva. Along the way he met some amazing people fostering the unique sense of community that surrounds the Haute Route.

 This will make you want to get out on your bike and ride!

If you'd like to contribute captions and video info in your language, here's the link üëç http://gcn.eu/pd

Watch more on GCN...
Preparing for a multi-stage event http://gcn.eu/PrepMS üìπ 
4 best ways to train for long climbs http://gcn.eu/Climb üìπ 

Photos: ¬© Bettiniphoto / http://www.bettiniphoto.net/ & ¬©Tim De Waele / http://www.tdwsport.com

Music: Jon Bj√∂rk - Percussive Trailer 4
Victor Olsson - High Energy Teens 5
Daniel Aldenmark - Into Forever (Instrumental)
Christian Nanzell - Rapier
Daniel Gunnarsson - Next Level
Henrik Andersson - Go!
Mikael Persson feat. Cecilia Axeland - Are You Holding On
Anders Schill Paulsen feat. Zakky Z - Better Days 3

About GCN:

The Global Cycling Network puts you in the centre of the action: from the iconic climbs of Alpe D‚ÄôHuez and Mont Ventoux to the cobbles of Flanders, everywhere there is road or pav√©, world-class racing and pro riders, we will be there bringing you action, analysis and unparalleled access every week, every month, and every year. We show you how to be a better cyclist with our bike maintenance videos, tips for improving your cycling, cycling top tens, and not forgetting the weekly GCN Show. Join us on YouTube‚Äôs biggest and best cycling channel to get closer to the action and improve your riding!

Welcome to the Global Cycling Network | Inside cycling

Thanks to our sponsors:

Alta Badia: http://gcn.eu/AltaBadia- // Maratona Dles Dolomites: http://gcn.eu/MaratonaDlesDolomites-
Assos of Switzerland: http://gcn.eu/Assos
KASK helmets: http://gcn.eu/KASK
fi‚Äôzi:k shoes and saddles: http://gcn.eu/fizikshoes and http://gcn.eu/fiziksaddles
Topeak tools: http://gcn.eu/Topeak
Canyon bikes: http://gcn.eu/-Canyon
Quarq: http://gcn.eu/Quarq
DT Swiss: http://gcn.eu/DtSwiss
Science in Sport: http://gcn.eu/SiS
Orbea bikes: http://gcn.eu/Orbea
Trek Bicycles: http://gcn.eu/-Trek
Vision wheels: http://gcn.eu/Vision
Zipp wheels: http://gcn.eu/Zipp
power2max: http://gcn.eu/power2max
Wahoo Fitness: http://gcn.eu/Wahoo-Fitness 
Park Tool: http://gcn.eu/-parktool
Continental tyres: http://gcn.eu/continental-
Camelbak: http://gcn.eu/camelbak-

The GCN Club - http://gcn.eu/club
YouTube Channel - http://gcn.eu/gcnYT
Facebook - http://gcn.eu/gcnFb
Instagram - http://gcn.eu/GCNInsta
Google+ - http://gcn.eu/gcnGPlus
Twitter - http://gcn.eu/gcnTW

Leave us a comment below!

videos.curation_reason: High-quality production covering the classic 7-day Alps event with detailed course breakdown and personal struggle narrative.

videos.title: Riding gravel bike around Matterhorn
videos.description:
That was a fun weekend in Zermatt - Switzerland, on my gravel bike.
From Zeneggen to Zermatt, then up-hill to Sch√∂nbielh√ºtte close to Matterhorn, and then the same way back.

My bike:
Triban GRVL 520 SRAM APEX 1

quotes.text: I had to push 450 watts to stay in so I shout like in my best friends do some more do some more if I do that for a minute I explode and as I'm approaching the top I just feel like I I'm reaching my limit.

22 kilometers of climbing very big very tough climb all the way up to 2200 meters from 1500 meters and up your power numbers are drastically going to decrease the air is thin there's less oxygen available so you're just not going to be able to push the same Powers as sea level.

It's hard it's really really hard but it's possible. Over 896 kilometers and over 22,000 meters of elevation lay ahead with the heat rising and fatigue building on stage two things were starting to get really tough.

key_challenges.name: Jebel Akhdar
key_challenges.description: 19 kilometers at 8% average gradient with 4 kilometers of 10.5%. Described as the most difficult climb ever done by the rider with seriously steep ramps hitting 20% in the first 10 meters. Unrelenting climb with extreme heat adding to the challenge.

key_challenges.name: Col du Izoard
key_challenges.description: The infamous climb that brought one rider to nearly giving up, described as one of the toughest tests on the route requiring support from fellow riders to complete.

key_challenges.name: 22km climb to 2200 meters
key_challenges.description: Long 22 kilometer climb from 1500 to 2200 meters elevation where power numbers drastically decrease due to thin air and less oxygen availability compared to sea level.

terrain_notes.text: Climbs feature seriously steep ramps with gradients hitting 20% in opening sections, making gear selection immediately critical.
High altitude sections above 1500 meters significantly impact power output due to thin air and reduced oxygen availability.

gear_mentions.text: 50/34 chainrings with 11-28 cassette recommended, with an 11-30 cassette as backup for the steepest sections.

race_day_tips.text: On extreme climbs, pace yourself and ride to power rather than trying to stay with faster riders early on the climb.
Nutrition is critical - big riders need to consume 800-1300 grams of carbs daily totaling 6000-8000 calories to maintain performance across multiple stages.
When struggling mentally on climbs, fellow riders can provide crucial support - accept help and consume nutrition even when you don't want to.

additional_quotes.text: The only thing we could find was a takeaway pizza so I had like a massive vegetable pizza with some tuna and then we went to the rider briefing with information about the next day they'll give you the weather to give you the stuff to look out for
After each stage preparation of the next stage starts right after the previous stage and actually the food might be the biggest Factor if you don't eat well the next day you're not gonna perform

There's one guy you helped yesterday the he's 71 is struggling with his head uses never done a truth that's one of the things they all do it you really get it right the first time he's never done it and at the bottom of the last climb yesterday she basically went to the Dominican says I'm done

rider_intel.search_text: Haute Route events are professionally supported multi-day stage races featuring extreme climbs across European mountain ranges. Riders face challenges like the 19km Jebel Akhdar climb in Oman with 8% average gradient and 20% ramps, and high-altitude Alpine climbs reaching 2200 meters where reduced oxygen significantly impacts power output. The Alps route covers 896 kilometers with over 22,000 meters of elevation gain across multiple stages. Each stage includes timed climbing sections with mandatory time limits riders must meet to continue. Gear recommendations include 50/34 chainrings with 11-28 or 11-30 cassettes for steep gradients. Nutrition becomes critical with larger riders needing 800-1300 grams of carbs daily. Events provide full support including marshals, neutral service, medical support, and rider briefings covering weather, climb details, and safety information. Mental challenges are common especially for first-time participants, but strong community support among riders helps people through difficult moments on climbs.
